label: Letter from Warren Hubert Moise to Edwin Warren Moise, August 9, 1934
description: In this two-page, handwritten letter, Warren Hubert Moise writes to his nephew Edwin Warren Moise (b. 1889), thanking him for the cards he sent from his trip to New Orleans. W. H. Moise describes the location of the old family home in Jefferson City, discusses inscriptions on the Moise tomb, and notes that his uncle Theodore Sidney Moise (b. 1808) was not buried in New Orleans; rather, "[h]is remains were taken to Charleston S.C." Moise concludes the letter by speculating on the location of "Uncle’s portrait" by Paul Edouard Poincy, whose name he misspells "Poincie."

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: In this two-page, handwritten letter, Warren Hubert Moise writes to his nephew Edwin Warren Moise (b. 1889), thanking him for the cards he sent from his trip to New Orleans. W. H. Moise describes the location of the old family home in Jefferson City, discusses inscriptions on the Moise tomb, and notes that his uncle Theodore Sidney Moise (b. 1808) was not buried in New Orleans; rather, "[h]is remains were taken to Charleston S.C." Moise concludes the letter by speculating on the location of "Uncle’s portrait" by Paul Edouard Poincy, whose name he misspells "Poincie."

metadata.label: Access Note
metadata.value: For more information contact Special Collections at Addlestone Library, College of Charleston, Charleston, SC, 29424.

metadata.label: Digitization Specifications

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
333 Kearny St.  
SAN FRANCISCO, CALIF.,  Aug. 9th 34
Dear Warren: –
I received the cards you and Marion sent me from N.O. Thank you for them.
Since my last to you my health has been so miserable I haven’t felt in the mood for writing but I can’t put off answering yours of June 6th any longer.
You didn’t say anything about the receipt of my letter introducing you to Uncle and his family. Did you receive it?
The old home on St Charles Ave. was in Jefferson City which was connected with N.O. by a steam R.R. that ran between what is now Lee’s Circle – out St Charles Ave – to Carrolton. Jefferson City was in Jefferson Parish I am sure, because when I was looking up the title to the old home I had to go accross [sic] the river to the Jefferson Parish Court house for them[?] – Orleans Parish now extends to just above Carrolton – When the change was made and this section became a part of N.O. I don’t know.
The inscriptions on the tomb – That giving Sister’s birth as “1936” is more or less guess. (over)
Lil wrote me at the time of Sister’s death for what information I could give and she figured out the date recorded with out any absolute knowledge of the facts.
“Emilie Hubert” – the name and dates were put on the family tomb, but I am certain her remains, like those of Warren, Louise, and Willie were never moved from Natchitoches.
Uncle was not buried in N.O. His remains were taking to Charleston S.C. I remember the circumstance a[s] I met Leonard at the train, when it passed through Montgomery. It was the first time I had seen Leonard for several years and the last time I met him.
So the old building at 28 Carondelet St. is still standing – it wasn’t modern 55 years ago – it has made quite a respectable age for an American business building.
You didn’t say whether Frank V. Moise was a son of Jim or Everest. Through him, particularly if he was Everest’s son, you might have got a chance to see Uncle’s portrait by Poincie. 
Glad you had a nice trip – I must stop now as I am getting a bit shakey [sic] – 
Kiss Marion and the baby for me
Affectionately
Uncle
